sections.title: Resources and Support
sections.subtitle: You don't have to navigate this alone - help is available

sections.title: Finding the Right Support
sections.content: Recovery from financial abuse requires multiple types of support - emotional, legal, financial, and practical. This lesson connects you with organizations and resources specifically designed to help survivors of financial abuse.

points.title: Crisis Hotlines
points.description: 24/7 confidential support, safety planning, and referrals to local resources. Trained advocates understand financial abuse.

points.title: Legal Aid
points.description: Free or low-cost legal assistance with divorce, custody, restraining orders, debt disputes, and credit issues.

points.title: Financial Counseling
points.description: Certified counselors who can help with budgeting, credit repair, debt management, and financial planning.

points.title: Emergency Assistance
points.description: Help with immediate needs like shelter, food, transportation, childcare, and medical care.

points.title: Job Training
points.description: Career counseling, skills training, resume help, and job placement assistance.

points.title: Support Groups
points.description: Connect with other survivors who understand your experience. Share strategies and build community.

links.label: National Domestic Violence Hotline
links.description: Call 1-800-799-7233 or text START to 88788 - 24/7 support

links.label: National Coalition Against Domestic Violence
links.description: Find local programs and state-specific resources

links.label: WomensLaw.org
links.description: Legal information and resources by state

links.label: National Foundation for Credit Counseling
links.description: Find certified financial counselors near you

sections.title: Financial-Specific Resources
sections.content: Several organizations focus specifically on the financial aspects of abuse recovery. These programs offer financial education, micro-loans, matched savings programs, and direct financial assistance to help survivors achieve independence.

links.label: FreeFrom
links.description: Cash assistance and financial security programs for survivors

links.label: Savvy Ladies
links.description: Free financial education and planning for women

sections.title: Safety When Seeking Help
sections.content: If you're still in an unsafe situation, take precautions when seeking help. Use a safe computer or phone, clear your browser history, use private/incognito mode, and consider using a public computer at a library. Many hotlines offer online chat options if calling isn't safe.

sections.title: Legal Resources
sections.content: Legal assistance is often free for domestic violence survivors. Legal aid organizations can help with protective orders, divorce, child custody, debt disputes, and housing issues. Many states have laws that protect survivors from being held responsible for debts incurred through coercion.

links.label: Legal Services Corporation
links.description: Find free legal aid in your area

links.label: National Center on Domestic Violence, Trauma & Mental Health
Victim Connect Resource Center
links.description: Referrals to local victim services - Call 1-855-484-2846

sections.title: Creating Your Support Team
steps: Contact a domestic violence advocate to create a comprehensive safety and recovery plan
Find a financial counselor who understands abuse dynamics
Connect with legal aid for advice on your specific situation
Join a support group (in-person or online) for survivors
Identify trusted friends or family members who can provide emotional support
Consider therapy with a counselor experienced in trauma and abuse
Build relationships with community resources (food banks, job centers, etc.)
Stay connected - isolation makes recovery harder

sections.title: You Deserve Support
sections.content: Asking for help is not a sign of weakness - it's a sign of strength and self-care. These resources exist because financial abuse is common, and recovery is possible. You deserve safety, independence, and a life free from abuse.

sections.title: Moving Forward
sections.content: Recovery is not linear. There will be setbacks and challenges. But with the right support and resources, you can rebuild your financial life and create the independence and security you deserve. Take it one step at a time, celebrate small victories, and remember that you are not alone.
